did.unittitle: R. L. Simon, New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee, Wisconsin 1921 Nov 7

scopecontent.p: States that he has no criticisms of Theodore Dreiser's work; suggests he asks editor of New York Evening Postfor bibliography; writes that Boni Liveright regards Dreiser as a great American realist and is proud to be his publisher; mentions public opinion, sales, and royalties.

did.unittitle: [W. W. Lange], Milwaukee, to Atlantic Monthly, New York 1921 Nov 28

scopecontent.p: Asks if they have any published or written criticism on Theodore Dreiser, particularly on Sister Carrie, Jennie Gerhardt, or The Financier; asks for opinions of Dreiser; praises Dreiser's work.

did.unittitle: [W. W. Lange], Milwaukee, to Literary Digest, New York 1921 Nov 28
Henry S. Canby to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Nov 30

scopecontent.p: Writes that he reviewed Theodore Dreiser's books when they appeared; respects Dreiser's work, but believes it is more substance than form.

did.unittitle: H. W. Ralston, New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 2

scopecontent.p: Discusses collection written material on Theodore Dreiser; mentions hiring Dreiser as associate editor of Smith's Magazine; knows Dreiser intimately; regrets they cannot do greater justice to Dreiser and his work.

did.unittitle: Editor, Atlantic Monthly, Boston, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 3

scopecontent.p: Discusses varied opinions of Theodore Dreiser's work and publishing difficulty with Sister Carrie.

did.unittitle: C. H. Holmes, Butterick Pat. Co., New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 5

scopecontent.p: Writes that he does not recall any criticisms of Dreiser's work that would interest him; suggests he get index to periodical literature in library where he can find references to Dreiser and his work.

did.unittitle: Alexander Harvey, New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 5

scopecontent.p: Includes TL carbon, 1921 Nov 28, W. W. Lange to Current Opinion; calls Theodore Dreiser a writer of power and Sister Carriea work of genius; believes Jennie Gerhardtreveals mastery of narrative and insight into human character; compliments The Financier; suggests her write Dreiser directly for clippings.

did.unittitle: William Lengel, New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 6

scopecontent.p: Includes TL carbon, 1921 Nov 28, W. W. Lange to Hearst's Publishing Co.; believes that Theodore Dreiser comes near to being America's greatest novelist of the time; suggests Boni & Liveright or H. L. Mencken could help in search.

did.unittitle: [W. W. Lange] to The Fortnightly Review1921 Dec 12

scopecontent.p: Copy of letter to Atlantic Monthly.

did.unittitle: Grant Richards, London, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 25

scopecontent.p: Explains that he has written letters praising Dreiser, but not for publication, excepting a quotation of him on jacket of Sister Carrie; writes that he cannot say where Dreiser's work is praised in England; argues he is one of the leading men of letters in the United States; suggests Frank Harris could tell where he wrote regarding Dreiser's work.

did.unittitle: W. L. Courtney, London, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1921 Dec 29

scopecontent.p: Writes that no article by Dreiser was published in Fortnightly Review; holds a very high opinion of his work; suggests he write to Arnold Bennett, Edmund Goose, and Hugh Walpole.

did.unittitle: W. George, New York, to W. W. Lange, New York 1922 Jan 14

scopecontent.p: Thinks of Dreiser as important, though he has never written of him; knows The Financierand The Geniusbest; believes Dreiser has captured flavor of American life, but is hampered by incoherence of form, crude ideas, and vulgar outlook; believes American literature to be more vital than that of England or France.

did.unittitle: S. W. Linn, Chicago, to W. W. w/envLange, MIlwaukee 1922 Apr 3

scopecontent.p: Writes that Sister Carrieis often called the most effective novel written by a Chicago author; compliments Jennie Gerhardt, and The Financier; thinks much less of The Titanand The Genius; thinks Theodore Dreiser's purpose is to present life as he sees it; comments on Dreiser's style, morality, and literary rank.

did.unittitle: John Farrar, Geo. Doran Co., New York, to W. W. Lange, Milwaukee 1924 Jan 23

scopecontent.p: Writes that Spotlighthas not yet analyzed Theodore Dreiser; refers him to article by Edward J. Smith, March 1921; compliments Dreiser's technique.

did.unittitle: "Professor [James Weber] Linn analyzes American fiction," 1922 Mar

scopecontent.p: Speech at College Club meeting; believes Sister Carrieto be a good book and The Titanto be a bad one; believes bad fiction is a menace to national taste.
